abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            report (ICR) for the Federal Highways Management and
            Rehabilitation Project in Brazil. The project, following on
            the Sixth and Seventh Highway Projects, was designed to
            continue assisting in modernizing the road subsector's
            organization and management and in strengthening its
            agencies. The project was successful in achieving its
            physical objectives but success was uneven in fulfilling
            institutional goals. Overall, Bank performance was
            satisfactory in terms of responsiveness to client needs,
            although with shortcomings. The Borrower's performance
            was unsatisfactory with respect to the provision of
            counterpart funds but satisfactory in terms of project
            coordination and monitoring, which contributed to reduced
            field supervision inputs by Bank staff. Among the lessons
            learned: 1) the decentralization process of a large highway
            network such as the federal system of Brazil involves
            regional, economic and political interests of large
            magnitude, and requires more time to mature and implement
            than was anticipated at appraisal; 2) counterpart funding
            problems adversely affected the implementation of the
            physical investment component of the project; 3) Bank
            supervision teams were often unable to identify delays and
            issues early enough to propose timely remedial measures; 4)
            The investments financed under the project were justified in
            economic terms, and technical solutions were optimized at
            the level of each individual investment; 5) Work programs
            should be based on a multi-year investment program supported
            by objective network survey and economic evaluation and not,
            as was often the case during implementation, on a stock of
            available project design studies launched on the basis of
            perceived needs by district engineers; 6) To be effective,
            the institutional components of projects need to more
            focused and address a few essential issues with realistic
            timetables and designs adapted to the capacity of the
            executing agency; and 7) Continuity in the Bank team during
            implementation had a positive and stabilizing influence
            during a period of many changes in National Road Department
            key personnel.
